title: Muse: Text-To-Image Generation via Masked Generative Transformers

last_post.content:
RT @nathanbenaich@twitter.com

Bye bye diffusion, hello latte art!

This is impressive, fast, and efficient.

Muse is a text-to-image Transformer model that achieves SOTA image generation performance while being significantly more efficient than diffusion or autoregressive models.

https://muse-model.github.io

🐦🔗: https://twitter.com/nathanbenaich/status/1610573440968179712

title: api.joinmastodon.org/statistic...

last_post.content:
The number of active Mastodon users — those who've logged in in the last 30 days — has fallen to 1.8 million from a high of 2.6 million. This reflects the fact that while there's a wave of new users after each Musk tantrum, the majority aren't sticking around. Even the 1.8M figure is inflated by new accounts, so I expect a further drop.

Still, the number of active users is over 4 times what it used to be before the Twitter takeover.

Source: https://api.joinmastodon.org/statistics (and Wayback machine).

title: 2022: The Year in Visual Stories and Graphics

last_post.content:
If you're even passingly interested in #dataviz / etc, take a few to compare these two offerings:

(1) The NYT's "2022: The Year in Visual Stories and Graphics" https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2022/12/28/us/2022-year-in-graphics.html

(2) "Tableau Public’s Viz Wrap: Interesting Data Visualizations from 2022" https://www.tableau.com/blog/tableau-public-viz-wrap-interesting-data-visualizations-2022

Even allowing for the fact that two projects are different in key ways — institutional capacity and context foremost among them — what strikes me is how flat, conventional, and superficially decorative the Tableau offerings are.

From the mid-'90s, when dataviz became more (yes) a pop phenomenon, it's struggled with how deeply its aesthetics are defined by the software tools designers relied on. They should have struggled *against* that, imo. But doing so would require a deeper understanding of the field's evolution over the last century than the obsessive recitation of names like Playfair and Minard (and, more recently, Nightingale and Dubois). The fixation on those historical figures is a classic bourgie move: using "classical" figures to signal tradition and legitimacy. (Datavizzies are way overdue for a new year's resolution to move on from that classic-rock stuff.)

I can be bitterly critical of the NYT, but its commitment to experimenting with journalistic form and content around dataviz is unparalleled. The fact that one institution could trot out its own work over just one year and *blow away* a more inwardly oriented dataviz roster says a lot.

title: 2022 in review: neuroAI comes of age

last_post.content:
It's time to unbundle science. I put in a lot of work writing blog posts. This last one (https://xcorr.net/2023/01/01/2022-in-review-neuroai-comes-of-age/) was 100+ hours in the making.

I could put in a few extra hours, reformat and submit to a preprint server to get citations. But it feels silly: lock up the research behind a pdf that's not mobile accessible, remove the convenient placement of the links for a bibliography, strip all the screenshots from the papers I link to... maybe I'd even need to change the voice to a mimic serious formal science and I don't want that.

So I'm experimental with unbundling science by making some of the artifacts citable. I released the figure I generated for this blog post on figshare, with a citable DOI. Let me know if you think this is useful. https://figshare.com/articles/figure/Typology_of_neuroAI/21818403

title: Papers and patents are becoming less disruptive over time - Nature

last_post.content:
Taking a closer look at this paper, I really dislike it.

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-022-05543-x

It's clear that newer papers *must* have a lower “disruption” score than older ones under a null model — they even confirm this in the supplemental material with a randomization test. It's an artifact of their definition.

When comparing with the null model they compute only the z-score, getting values at most 4 or so. It's also besides the point — as usual, small meaningless deviations from the null model can be statistically “significant.” Effect size ≠ statistical significance.

Finally, according to their definition, review papers would be “disruptive” because they funnel a bunch of citations. And a paper that does not cite anyone but is universally cited would not be “disruptive”. 🤷

@networkscience
@academicchatter
#networkscience #networks

title: ‘Disruptive’ science has declined — and no one knows why

I don't necessarily disagree with this take.

But there does seem to me to also be the possibility that most of the low-hanging fruit got picked. If our model of the world is roughly right within the parameters we normally operate, there won't be many radical disruptions.

RT @eric_mccorkle@twitter.com

https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-022-04577-5

Alright... I'm coming out of Twitter retirement to unload on this.

We know damn well why.

title: How Twitter misleads us about how many people have left — and what to do about it

last_post.content:
Who do so many people seem unaware of the mass exodus from Twitter?

Social media feeds are engines for distorting our social understanding. But we can push back against the algorithm, with a simple automated out-of-office message on Twitter (how-to included).

This post explains the science of social influence that allows Twitter to maintain an illusion of a full room, how to change that, & why we need industry-independent science for our digital environments.

https://natematias.medium.com/how-twitter-misleads-us-about-how-many-people-have-left-and-what-to-do-about-it-bba484b6fed6

title: Dividing a Square into Similar Rectangles

last_post.content:
If you don't know what this is about start reading a summary by @johncarlosbaez here: https://johncarlosbaez.wordpress.com/2022/12/22/dividing-a-square-into-similar-rectangles/

In this thread I will prove here that the allowed ratios in a similar-rectangulation with \(N\) rectangles are always zeros of a polynomial of degree at most \(N\).

For every (generic) rectangulation there is a pair of directed graphs recording the relative positions of the rectangles, a horizontal graph and a vertical graph.
1/n

title: Petals – Decentralized platform for running 100B+ language models

last_post.content: it annoys me that applications of large language models continue to depend on big-company centralized computing infrastructure, even as text-to-image models become more locally runnable. this looks like an interesting potential (stopgap?) solution: a BitTorrent-style swarm in which each participating machine hosts a small chunk of the full model, enabling distributed inference + fine-tuning https://petals.ml

title: COVID Data Tracker

last_post.content: - XBB.1.5 is surging very rapidly, having increased 10x from 4% of US cases to 41% in just three weeks (https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#variant-proportions). It grew out of NY and has become predominant in the northeast US, and experts predict it will spread across the US in the coming weeks. In the past two years, the first week of January was the peak of holiday surges, but this year, it appears we'll see increased transmission and risks throughout January.

title: The Work of Martin Ravallion: A Round-up of Influential Research from an Exceptional Poverty Economist

If you’re just learning of Ravallion’s work, here’s a micro-summary of each of his 15 most cited (per year since publication) articles.

https://www.cgdev.org/blog/work-martin-ravallion-round-influential-research-exceptional-poverty-economist

Rest in peace, Professor Ravallion. My gratitude goes out to you for your leadership and your research.

title: Why do economists so dislike "conditional independence"?

last_post.content: Interesting post by Scott Cunningham on how conditional independence goes against rationality (people choosing the treatment based on expected benefits) and that's why economists don't like this assumption: https://causalinf.substack.com/p/why-do-economists-so-dislike-conditional Perhaps a corollary might be that selection on observables then becomes more plausible when the "treatment" is not something you choose based on a rational calculation but instead is something like a feeling or a personality trait or some aspect of your environment.

title: https://elicit.org

last_post.content:
While ChatGPT is all the rage these days, as you may know it doesn't optimize for accuracy, but rather something like plausability.

I would thus like to highlight an alternative that only answers based on scientific papers, and does so while referencing all the sources:

https://elicit.org

To me, this is pretty awesome! Let's encourage this type of projects that promote accuracy and transparency of its sources!

title: Facebook Wanted Out of Politics. It Was Messier Than Anyone Expected.

last_post.content:
There are two pieces of news in this one:

https://www.wsj.com/articles/facebook-politics-controls-zuckerberg-meta-11672929976?mod=tech_lead_pos2
 
1.     In late 2021, with zero fanfare, Facebook began changing newsfeed worldwide to exclude comments and reshares in how it promotes politics, societal and health-related content.

2.     This wasn’t enough for FB’s leadership and board. Late in 2021, they asked Facebook to move forward with zero-weighting ALL civic content in newsfeed. Facebook wanted out of politics.

title: Republican Party Stumbles Through the Wilderness With No Clear Leaders

last_post.content:
Did anyone see this Hallelujah paragraph in the New York Times today? Here's the part we celebrate. (Context is the current melt down of the Republican party...)

"That ideology of destruction defies characterization by traditional political labels like moderate or conservative."

https://www.nytimes.com/2023/01/05/us/politics/republican-party-leadership.html

Did you hear that? The Times politics desk is now admitting that "conservative" is not a good name for the MAGA forces overtaking the GOP.

And it only took 12 years!

#journalism #uspolitics

title: Twitter Hit With $228.9m Copyright Infringement / Repeat Infringer Lawsuit

last_post.content:
#Twitter may lose its #SafeHarbor protection because it's not responding to #takedown notices for repeat #copyright infringers.
https://torrentfreak.com/twitter-hit-with-228-9m-copyright-infringement-repeat-infringer-lawsuit-230104/

The article doesn't say so, but it seems that Twitter isn't responding to the takedown notices as US law requires ("expeditiously") because of the #Musk layoffs.

This is big. #SocialMedia platforms cannot operate in the US without a safe harbor from copyright lawsuits. It's as if Musk sawed off the wings of his plane to save weight.

title: What explains recent tech layoffs, and why should we be worried? | Stanford News

last_post.content:
Fun fact - #layoffs are a social contagion amongst businesses, and do little (to nothing) to actually help companies recover during economic downturns.

Don’t take my word for it - this comes from years of study and scholarly research:

https://news.stanford.edu/2022/12/05/explains-recent-tech-layoffs-worried/

title: 95%-ile isn't that good

last_post.content:
Even though they're technically not contradictory, I'm not sure how to reconcile the following two things:

1. Nearly every time an outsider says that people are doing X stupidly and could do way better, they're wrong for boring reasons that are obvious to any insider.

2. It seems fairly easy* to find huge wins as an outsider.

At some level, maybe this is like https://danluu.com/p95-skill/, where the median player in an objective-based game regularly loses because they don't touch the objective, but
